docs.snippet: They called it Southampton Place. To most people in Houston, it was the name of a neighborhood known for expensive homes and influential residents.    But to a small group of executives at the Enron Corporation, it meant something far different: t...
docs.lead_paragraph: They called it Southampton Place. To most people in Houston, it was the name of a neighborhood known for expensive homes and influential residents. But to a small group of executives at the Enron Corporation, it meant something far different: the opportunity to obtain millions of dollars of cash, fast, with the money coming from the company's own coffers.
docs.abstract: Report released by special committee of board of bankrupt Enron Corp describes lucrative investments in Southhampton, limited partnership involved in dealings with Enron partnerships; partnerships gave small group of Enron executives opportunity to obtain millions of dollars of fast cash, with money coming from company's own coffers; insiders made millions in profits in secret deals with some of partnerships that ultimately brought company to its knees (M)

headline.main: Deal at Enron Gave Insiders Fast Fortunes

docs.snippet: After a weekend of sharp criticism for his stewardship of Enron, Kenneth L. Lay, the company's former chief executive, abruptly reversed course this evening and told Congress he would refuse to testify before two committees preparing to hear his t...
docs.lead_paragraph: After a weekend of sharp criticism for his stewardship of Enron, Kenneth L. Lay, the company's former chief executive, abruptly reversed course this evening and told Congress he would refuse to testify before two committees preparing to hear his testimony, starting on Monday. Earl J. Silbert, the lawyer for Mr. Lay, said he had decided to withdraw because ''judgments have been reached and the tenor of the hearings will be prosecutorial.'' But Congressional aides said that they had never expected that Mr. Lay would appear and that he was looking for a convenient excuse to miss the hearings.
docs.abstract: Kenneth L Lay, former chief executive of Enron Corp, tells Congress he will refuse to testify before two committees, following weekend of sharp criticism for his stewardship of company; Lay's lawyer, Earl J Silbert, claims judgments have already been reached and hearings will be prosecutorial; over weekend, some lawmakers appearing on talk programs suggest that crimes might have been committed at Enron; also, special committee of Enron's board provides new details of self-dealing and financial sleight-of-hand that substantially overstated earnings and characterizes Lay as responsible in overall sense for company's problems; Congressional aides say Lay was looking for excuse to avoid testifying (M)

headline.main: At 11th Hour, Lay Refuses to Testify as Congressional Criticism Grows More Pointed

byline.original: By STEPHEN LABATON and RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr

docs.snippet: Though the General Accounting Office plans to sue the White House to learn how much influence Enron and other energy companies had on the Bush administration's energy policies, one scorecard has been publicly available for months.    In its Nation...
docs.lead_paragraph: Though the General Accounting Office plans to sue the White House to learn how much influence Enron and other energy companies had on the Bush administration's energy policies, one scorecard has been publicly available for months. In its National Energy Strategy, a 170-page list of recommendations released in May, the Bush administration detailed its views on regulating electricity transmission, using coal and natural gas resources and controlling pollution, all vital to Enron.
docs.abstract: Bush administration, in its national energy strategy, details its views on regulating electricity transmission, using coal and natural gas resources and controlling pollution, all vital to Enron; company and its executives were among largest contributors to Pres Bush, and company officials including former chief executive Kenneth L Lay had at least five meetings with administration officials to discuss energy; company's record on shaping administration approach is mixed (M)

headline.main: Enron Won Some and Lost Some in White House Energy Report
headline.kicker: ENRON'S MANY STRANDS: THE ENERGY TASK FORCE

docs.snippet: Following is a transcript of President Bush's State of the Union address, as recorded by The New York Times:    The War on Terror      As we gather tonight, our nation is at war, our economy is in recession and the civilized world faces unpreceden...
docs.lead_paragraph: Following is a transcript of President Bush's State of the Union address, as recorded by The New York Times: The War on Terror As we gather tonight, our nation is at war, our economy is in recession and the civilized world faces unprecedented dangers. Yet the state of our union has never been stronger.
docs.abstract: Transcript of Pres Bush's State of the Union address, as recorded by The New York Times; photo (M)

headline.main: President Bush's State of the Union Address to Congress and the Nation

docs.snippet: AS the stock plummeted, investors and employees alike were left with big losses. But one group of shareholders came out ahead -- management. Many board members and top executives managed to sell millions of dollars of shares before the big fall an...
docs.lead_paragraph: AS the stock plummeted, investors and employees alike were left with big losses. But one group of shareholders came out ahead -- management. Many board members and top executives managed to sell millions of dollars of shares before the big fall and still have something to show for the stock's once-lofty price. This is the story of Enron, of course, but it hardly ends there. Over the last two years, as the stock market has fallen about 30 percent from its peak, the description fits dozens of other companies as well.
docs.abstract: David Leonhardt Economic View column on how many corporate executives benefited financially like Enron executives by selling millions of dollar of shares before fall; says when economic system richly rewards certain behavior, no one should be surprised when that behavior becomes norm; holds if Americans want to change it, they have to change incentives; adds Enron mess has potential to focus people's attention on complicated task of doing that; graph (M)

headline.main: Enron's Way: Pay Packages Foster Spin, Not Results

docs.snippet: Because of an editing error, an article on Sunday summarizing the previous week's developments in the collapse of the Enron Corporation misstated the timing of an online chat session in which the company's chairman, Kenneth L. Lay, answered employ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Because of an editing error, an article on Sunday summarizing the previous week's developments in the collapse of the Enron Corporation misstated the timing of an online chat session in which the company's chairman, Kenneth L. Lay, answered employees' questions. It was conducted on Sept. 26, not in October.
docs.abstract: Correction of Jan 20 article: Enron chairman Kenneth L Lay held online chat answering employees questions Sept 26, not in Oct
docs.section_name: Technology; Corrections; New York and Region

docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Among the startling revelations in the Enron mess is that Enron paid no federal corporate income taxes for four of the last five years (front page, Jan. 17)....
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Among the startling revelations in the Enron mess is that Enron paid no federal corporate income taxes for four of the last five years (front page, Jan. 17).
docs.abstract: Letter from Michael J Zimmer says startling revelation about Enron Corp is that it paid no federal corporate income taxes for four of last five years (Jan 17 article)

headline.main: The Enron Mess: Outrage, and Then?

docs.snippet: By 11:30 a.m., the tables at the Downtown Café, a Chinese restaurant across the street from the headquarters of the Enron Corporation, were usually beginning to fill up with crisply dressed lunchgoers.    These days, a patron can choose from rows...
docs.lead_paragraph: By 11:30 a.m., the tables at the Downtown Café, a Chinese restaurant across the street from the headquarters of the Enron Corporation, were usually beginning to fill up with crisply dressed lunchgoers. These days, a patron can choose from rows of empty tables, and Paul Chan, the manager, spends his time wondering how a rich corporate neighbor could go bust so quickly.

headline.main: The Hometown's Consuming Monthlong Soap Opera

docs.snippet: With the Justice Department and Congress ratcheting up investigations into the Enron Corporation, President Bush is seeking to play down his relationship with Enron's embattled chairman, Kenneth L. Lay. But their ties are broad and deep and go bac...
docs.lead_paragraph: With the Justice Department and Congress ratcheting up investigations into the Enron Corporation, President Bush is seeking to play down his relationship with Enron's embattled chairman, Kenneth L. Lay. But their ties are broad and deep and go back many years, and the relationship has been beneficial to both. In the Oval Office yesterday, Mr. Bush said that Mr. Lay ''was a supporter of Ann Richards in my run in 1994'' for governor of Texas and that he first got to know Mr. Lay after that race.
docs.abstract: Pres Bush's ties with Enron's embattled chairman, Kenneth L Lay, are broad, deep and of long standing and have been beneficial to both; Bush says that Lay supported Ann Richards in 1994 Texas gubernatorial race and that he got to know Lay after that race, but Lay and his wife gave $37,500 to Bush in that race -- three times the amount they gave to Richards; Lay has also told interviewers that he became very close to Bush before race; Bush has been strong advocate of many of issues most important to Enron, like deregulating electricity markets and curbing large civil jury awards; Democrats hope to turn friendship into political liability for Bush, while White House, in turn, seeks to distance administration from both Lay and Enron; photos (M)

headline.main: Bush and Democrats Disputing Ties to Enron

byline.original: By RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr. and DON VAN NATTA Jr

docs.snippet: ANYONE expecting fireworks last week at the first bankruptcy hearing of the Enron Corporation, the biggest corporate failure in American history, was quickly disabused of that notion by the judge, Arthur J. Gonzalez.     He told the packed room in...
docs.lead_paragraph: ANYONE expecting fireworks last week at the first bankruptcy hearing of the Enron Corporation, the biggest corporate failure in American history, was quickly disabused of that notion by the judge, Arthur J. Gonzalez. He told the packed room in federal bankruptcy court in Lower Manhattan that he was running the hearing as he would any standard initial proceeding for a company that seeks protection from debts; then he said most of the creditors would have no opportunity to speak. When a pile of documents arrived well into the hearing, outlining an emergency proposal for Enron to borrow money, the judge immediately called an hourlong recess so he could read them all.
docs.abstract: Profile of Judge Arthur J Gonzalez, who will be overseeingg bankruptcy proceedings of Enron Corp in Manhattan; he is no stranger to high-profile bankruptcies; photo (M)

headline.main: PrivateSector; In Re Enron, a Judge of Caution
